ELIMINATION OF EXAMS
Speaking of eliminating the final Senior examinations, have you
ever heard of the system in vogue at Barnard and at Smith? At these
institutions the student is not only free from the strain of exams, but
is unhindered by the existence of marks of any sort.
According to the Honor System in use at these colleges, the
student is apprenticed to some member of the faculty who is enough
in touch with his pupil's work to recommend him for a degree upon
the completion of the necessary amount of work. No roll is called
and the entire matter is left entirely to the student who is presupposed to have entered college for the purpose of benefiting himself.
As under other systems, there are probably work-dodgers, handshakers, and horseshoe artists at these institutions, but it is just as
reasonable to believe that the degree which they receive is thoroughly
earned as it is at a school where similar artists arrange for credit
according to the mark system.
Even if this apprenticeship idea is conceded to have its faults,
there is certainly no reason why it should not be applied in some form
in the last half of the fourth year of a college course. If a student
has earned, according to the mark system, seven-eighths of a college
degree, then he can certainly be trusted to absorb the other eighth
without the torture of final exams. And no man can sit in a lectureroom for a semester without absorbing the most of his course. If a
Senior can't be trusted for the final lap of his college career, then he
is out of place in an institution where the honor system is in force.
Examinations, especially finals, are not a test; they are a threat.

ELIMINATION OF EXAMS
Speaking of eliminating the final Senior examinations, have you
ever heard of the system in vogue at Barnard and at Smith? At these
institutions the student is not only free from the strain of exams, but
is unhindered by the existence of marks of any sort.
According to the Honor System in use at these colleges, the
student is apprenticed to some member of the faculty who is enough
in touch with his pupil's work to recommend him for a degree upon
the completion of the necessary amount of work. No roll is called
and the entire matter is left entirely to the student who is presupposed to have entered college for the purpose of benefiting himself.
As under other systems, there are probably work-dodgers, handshakers, and horseshoe artists at these institutions, but it is just as
reasonable to believe that the degree which they receive is thoroughly
earned as it is at a school where similar artists arrange for credit
according to the mark system.
Even if this apprenticeship idea is conceded to have its faults,
there is certainly no reason why it should not be applied in some form
in the last half of the fourth year of a college course. If a student
has earned, according to the mark system, seven-eighths of a college
degree, then he can certainly be trusted to absorb the other eighth
without the torture of final exams. And no man can sit in a lectureroom for a semester without absorbing the most of his course. If a
Senior can't be trusted for the final lap of his college career, then he
is out of place in an institution where the honor system is in force.
Examinations, especially finals, are not a test; they are a threat.
